docs.lead_paragraph: My insurance plan requires me to fill certain prescriptions by mail order. But I have always preferred to obtain medications from my neighborhood pharmacy in the New York suburbs, even though it means paying for them out of my own pocket.
docs.abstract: As more insurance companies turn to less expensive mail-order pharmacies, it is increasingly hard to fill medications locally.
docs.snippet: As more insurance companies turn to less expensive mail-order pharmacies, it is increasingly hard to fill medications locally.

docs.lead_paragraph: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.
docs.abstract: Changes in public policy produce changes in people's behavior, and not always what the policy makers intended, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The disease was called “shaking palsy” before it took the name of James Parkinson.

headline.seo: Parkinson’s Disease, Before It Got Its Name

docs.snippet: The disease was called “shaking palsy” before it took the name of James Parkinson.

docs.lead_paragraph: For at least 2,000 years Chinese healers have used acupuncture to treat pain and other ailments. Now Western doctors want proof that it works. There is little dispute that people feel better after receiving the treatment, in which thin needles are inserted deeply into the skin at specific points on the body. But are they benefiting from acupuncture itself, or just getting a placebo effect?

headline.main: Studying Acupuncture, One Needle Prick at a Time

docs.abstract: Study finds that acupuncture treatments given to arthritis patients to reduce knee pain were no more effective than sham treatments; critics of study conducted by Dr Maria E Suarez-Almazor of MD Anderson Cancer Center hold that study was poorly conceived; say it actually supports use of acupuncture for pain, as both sham treatments and acupuncture did make participants feel better; this research, which is published in journal Arthritis Care and Research, and other studies continue debate over effectiveness of acupuncture as treatment for pain; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For at least 2,000 years Chinese healers have used acupuncture to treat pain and other ailments. Now Western doctors want proof that it works.     There is little dispute that people feel better after receiving the treatment, in which thin needles...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is in recess, and there are no Food and Drug Administration scientific panels meeting this week.

The Obama administration is rewriting new rules on medical privacy after an outpouring of criticism from consumer groups and members of Congress who say the rules do not adequately protect the rights of patients.
